elements.content: A series of mixed-linker metal–organic frameworks [Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2] n containing substituted isophthalate linkers (Xiso2–; X = OH or CH3 or NH2 or H) and 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone pillars (pcih) have been prepared by using both solution and mechanochemical methods. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals their interdigitated two-dimensional structures with different arrangements of layers, dependent on hydrogen bonding and CH···π interactions involving the substituents and/or linkers. These supramolecular interactions are responsible for the formation of interlayer pores of various volumes, shapes, and dimensionality. All materials exhibit selective gas adsorption of CO2 over N2 with diverse profiles. Polar groups (OH and NH2) of the isophthalate linkers increase chemical affinity to carbon dioxide as well as hydrolytic and thermal stability of the frameworks.
elements.clean_text: A series of mixed-linker metal-organic frameworks [Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2] n  containing substituted isophthalate linkers (Xiso2-; X = OH or CH3 or NH2 or H) and 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone pillars (pcih) have been prepared by using both solution and mechanochemical methods. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals their interdigitated two-dimensional structures with different arrangements of layers, dependent on hydrogen bonding and CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions involving the substituents and/or linkers. These supramolecular interactions are responsible for the formation of interlayer pores of various volumes, shapes, and dimensionality. All materials exhibit selective gas adsorption of CO2 over N2 with diverse profiles. Polar groups (OH and NH2) of the isophthalate linkers increase chemical affinity to carbon dioxide as well as hydrolytic and thermal stability of the frameworks.

elements.content: A series of mixed-linker layered zinc-organic frameworks containing substituted isophthalate linkers and isonicotinoyl hydrazone pillars have been prepared to investigate the effect of the isophthalate substituent on supramolecular structures, stability, and gas adsorption properties.
elements.clean_text: A series of mixed-linker layered zinc-organic frameworks containing substituted isophthalate linkers and isonicotinoyl hydrazone pillars have been prepared to investigate the effect of the isophthalate substituent on supramolecular structures, stability, and gas adsorption properties.

elements.content: In recent years, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have been attracting considerable scientific interest due to their potential use in various fields of modern industry, e.g., gas storage and separation, catalysis, drug delivery, electronic devices, and others. Such applications are closely related to their remarkable properties such as high internal surface areas, nearly limitless crystal engineering possibilities, as well as unique and versatile structural flexibility and responsivity. The latter behavior of MOFs can be triggered by various stimuli and is enabled by labile intraframework metal-coordination bonds or by weaker interframework interactions (e.g., hydrogen bonds, van der Waals forces). Selected recent reports on unprecedented MOF dynamics include negative gas adsorption phenomenon, self-accelerating sorption, and reversible three-step reaction cycle for a family of layered MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have been attracting considerable scientific interest due to their potential use in various fields of modern industry, e.g., gas storage and separation, catalysis, drug delivery, electronic devices, and others. Such applications are closely related to their remarkable properties such as high internal surface areas, nearly limitless crystal engineering possibilities, as well as unique and versatile structural flexibility and responsivity. The latter behavior of MOFs can be triggered by various stimuli and is enabled by labile intraframework metal-coordination bonds or by weaker interframework interactions (e.g., hydrogen bonds, van der Waals forces). Selected recent reports on unprecedented MOF dynamics include negative gas adsorption phenomenon, self-accelerating sorption, and reversible three-step reaction cycle for a family of layered MOFs.

elements.content: There is a wide range of well developed tools for the design, engineering, and synthesis of MOF materials which enable the control of pore size, chemical affinity, stability, and other properties of porous coordination polymers. The desirable MOF properties including stimuli-responsive behaviors can be achieved not only through a careful choice of metal centers and organic struts but also by more sophisticated methods such as chemical reactions within a metal center or linker, replacement of guests molecules or even whole building blocks, as well as controlling electronic properties utilizing structural defects and downsizing effects. Although the methods of synthesis of MOFs are well-known, the majority of them require an organic solvent, relatively long reaction times, and heating. However, since the influential work of James et al., who showed that an extended MOF can be facilely prepared by 10 min of grinding dry components in a mortar, solvent-free methods have been introduced as an ecological and cost-effective alternative to conventional synthesis of porous coordination polymers.

The desirable MOF properties including stimuli-responsive behaviors can be achieved not only through a careful choice of metal centers and organic struts but also by more sophisticated methods such as chemical reactions within a metal center or linker, replacement of guests molecules or even whole building blocks, as well as controlling electronic properties utilizing structural defects and downsizing effects. Although the methods of synthesis of MOFs are well-known, the majority of them require an organic solvent, relatively long reaction times, and heating. However, since the influential work of James et al., who showed that an extended MOF can be facilely prepared by 10 min of grinding dry components in a mortar, solvent-free methods have been introduced as an ecological and cost-effective alternative to conventional synthesis of porous coordination polymers.

elements.content: Sustaining the worldwide environment requires appropriate porous materials for adsorption and separation of CO2 from exhaust gases. MOFs, with their high external surface, frequently combined with selective adsorption of carbon dioxide, have emerged as a reasonable class of materials for this urgent environmental problem. Along with the chemical affinity toward the greenhouse gas, there are additional requirements imposed on MOFs. Apart from the creation of specific interactions between a framework and CO2, the material must also be chemically (e.g., hydrolytically) and thermally stable. With regard to the former, very stable MOFs even in strongly alkaline solutions were reported recently. However, both academic and industrial societies need to put efforts into deep understanding of MOF modi operandi including stability, selectivity, and structure as well as the subtle interrelationship between these features.
elements.clean_text: Sustaining the worldwide environment requires appropriate porous materials for adsorption and separation of CO2 from exhaust gases. Apart from the creation of specific interactions between a framework and CO2, the material must also be chemically (e.g., hydrolytically) and thermally stable. With regard to the former, very stable MOFs even in strongly alkaline solutions were reported recently. However, both academic and industrial societies need to put efforts into deep understanding of MOF modi operandi including stability, selectivity, and structure as well as the subtle interrelationship between these features.

elements.content: Herein, we present the synthesis, crystal structure, sorption properties, and stability studies for a family of new mixed-linker MOFs {[Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2]­·guest} n constructed from 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (pcih) and 5-substituted isophthalate ions [Xiso2–, where X = OH (1); CH3 (2); NH2 (3); H (4-4b)]. All studied frameworks consist of the same neutral pcih linker belonging to a class of acylhydrazones, which possess CO and N–H functional groups. In response to environmental expectations, we show that zinc MOFs can be easily prepared by grinding solid reactants with a small amount of a liquid, as an alternative to syntheses in solution. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments reveal that the frameworks 1–4b are interdigitated layered coordination polymers built from metal-carboxylate clusters containing double pcih struts, similar as in the CID family, but with the key difference being structure-directing functional groups on N-donor linkers. The obtained new MOFs differ in a substituent on the isophthalate linker, which provides an excellent opportunity to study the influence of pendant side groups on their structures as well as on the relationship between the structure and properties, including gas adsorption and stability. In the literature, changes of linker pendant groups have been shown to influence MOF topology, structural flexibility, and stability. In this work we present the effect of intermolecular interactions on mutual orientation of MOF layers, their CO2 and N2 sorption properties, as well as thermal and hydrolytic stability.

All studied frameworks consist of the same neutral pcih linker belonging to a class of acylhydrazones, which possess CO and N-H functional groups. In response to environmental expectations, we show that zinc MOFs can be easily prepared by grinding solid reactants with a small amount of a liquid, as an alternative to syntheses in solution. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments reveal that the frameworks 1-4b are interdigitated layered coordination polymers built from metal-carboxylate clusters containing double pcih struts, similar as in the CID family, but with the key difference being structure-directing functional groups on N-donor linkers. The obtained new MOFs differ in a substituent on the isophthalate linker, which provides an excellent opportunity to study the influence of pendant side groups on their structures as well as on the relationship between the structure and properties, including gas adsorption and stability. In the literature, changes of linker pendant groups have been shown to influence MOF topology, structural flexibility, and stability. In this work we present the effect of intermolecular interactions on mutual orientation of MOF layers, their CO2 and N2 sorption properties, as well as thermal and hydrolytic stability.

elements.content: A family of microporous mixed-ligand two-dimensional (2D) metal–organic frameworks {[Zn2(Xiso)2­(pcih)2]­·guest} n has been prepared using 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (pcih), 5-substituted isophthalic acids [H2Xiso, where X= OH (1); CH3 (2); NH2 (3); H (4, 4b)] and diverse sources of zinc­(II) cations. In all reactions the in situ deprotonated dicarboxylic acids compensate positive charge of zinc­(II) ions and link them into one-dimensional double chains. The zinc-carboxylate chains are further connected by neutral pcih linkers as evidenced by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). Pale yellow crystals suitable for SCXRD (except 3) were grown in a sealed vessel by heating the solution containing N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/water (1–4) or N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA)/water (4b), appropriate ligands and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O ( and ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

A family of microporous mixed-ligand two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic frameworks {[Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2]⋅guest} n  has been prepared using 4-pyridinecarbaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (pcih), 5-substituted isophthalic acids [H2Xiso, where X= OH (1); CH3 (2); NH2 (3); H (4, 4b)] and diverse sources of zinc(II) cations. In all reactions the in situ deprotonated dicarboxylic acids compensate positive charge of zinc(II) ions and link them into one-dimensional double chains. The zinc-carboxylate chains are further connected by neutral pcih linkers as evidenced by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). Pale yellow crystals suitable for SCXRD (except 3) were grown in a sealed vessel by heating the solution containing N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/water (1-4) or N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA)/water (4b), appropriate ligands and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O ( and ).

elements.content: Alternatively, all coordination polymers (1–4b) can be obtained quantitatively in a mechanochemical reaction where Zn­(CH3COO)2­·2H2O, pcih and H2Xiso are ground together with a small amount of DMF or DMA (known as LAG - liquid assisted grinding). Apart from acting as a diffusion facilitating medium, the additive molecules fill the voids of frameworks 1–4b upon their formation. This procedure requires a small ratio of liquid volume to weight of reactants (η) within the range of 0.80–0.82 μL/mg and is completed in a short period of time (approximately 15 min). Tuning of mechanochemical synthetic conditions in the case of 4 was described earlier in detail. The comparison of the two synthetic approaches clearly shows that mechanosynthesis meets the requirements of green chemistry, but does not lead to the formation of single crystals of 1–4b suitable for SCXRD. The purity of all microporous mixed-linker MOFs, representing rare coordination polymers of the type [Zn2(Xiso)2(lig)2] n (lig = neutral ligand), was confirmed by elemental analysis (see ), infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), as well as powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (see Figure S1).

Apart from acting as a diffusion facilitating medium, the additive molecules fill the voids of frameworks 1-4b upon their formation. This procedure requires a small ratio of liquid volume to weight of reactants (η) within the range of 0.80-0.82 μL/mg and is completed in a short period of time (approximately 15 min). Tuning of mechanochemical synthetic conditions in the case of 4 was described earlier in detail. The comparison of the two synthetic approaches clearly shows that mechanosynthesis meets the requirements of green chemistry, but does not lead to the formation of single crystals of 1-4b suitable for SCXRD. The purity of all microporous mixed-linker MOFs, representing rare coordination polymers of the type [Zn2(Xiso)2(lig)2] n   (lig = neutral ligand), was confirmed by elemental analysis (see ), infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), as well as powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (see Figure S1).

elements.content: A series of metal–organic frameworks [Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2] n (1–4b) were prepared using a neutral acylhydrazone ligand (pcih) bearing both N–H and CO functional groups, appropriate isophthalic acid H2Xiso and initial zinc­(II) reactant. Single-crystals of 1, 2, 4, and 4b suitable for X-ray diffraction were selected from the bulk. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are shown in . The frameworks 1, 2, and 4 crystallize in a triclinic P1̅ space group, wherein mere exchange of DMF guest molecules in the latter (4) with DMA leads to monoclinic C2/c system (4b). All of the mixed-linker frameworks have the same layered topology. In the case of 3, its isostructurality with the rest of MOFs was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S1g). In each of the frameworks, the μ3-κ2,κ1,κ1-X-iso2– anions links neighboring nodes of Zn2 clusters into one-dimensional double chains, and the chains are further pillared by pcih ligands which increases the coordination network dimensionality to 2D (). The layers are arranged in an interdigitated ABAB manner and form porous structures with interlayer voids occupied by solvent molecules. The coordination geometry of zinc atoms in each cluster is disordered octahedral wherein equatorial positions are occupied by oxygen atoms from three different Xiso2– ligands and two N pyridyl atoms of μ2-pcih ligands completing the coordination sphere through axial coordination (a). The Zn(1)–N(11) and Zn(1)–N(12) in all MOFs are of almost identical lengths (Table S1), unlike Zn–O bonds where Zn(1)–O(71) is elongated as compared to the other zinc–oxygen bonds. However, the Zn(1)–O(71) bond in 2 is considerably shorter than in other frameworks (Table S1) which is strictly associated with its noninvolvement in hydrogen bonding, observed for all other MOF structures ().
elements.clean_text:
Structure

A series of metal-organic frameworks [Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2] n  (1-4b) were prepared using a neutral acylhydrazone ligand (pcih) bearing both N-H and CO functional groups, appropriate isophthalic acid H2Xiso and initial zinc(II) reactant. Single-crystals of 1, 2, 4, and 4b suitable for X-ray diffraction were selected from the bulk. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are shown in . The frameworks 1, 2, and 4 crystallize in a triclinic P1̅ space group, wherein mere exchange of DMF guest molecules in the latter (4) with DMA leads to monoclinic C2/c system (4b). All of the mixed-linker frameworks have the same layered topology. In the case of 3, its isostructurality with the rest of MOFs was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S1g). In each of the frameworks, the μ3-κ2,κ1,κ1-X-iso2- anions links neighboring nodes of Zn2 clusters into one-dimensional double chains, and the chains are further pillared by pcih ligands which increases the coordination network dimensionality to 2D (). The layers are arranged in an interdigitated ABAB manner and form porous structures with interlayer voids occupied by solvent molecules. The coordination geometry of zinc atoms in each cluster is disordered octahedral wherein equatorial positions are occupied by oxygen atoms from three different Xiso2- ligands and two N pyridyl atoms of μ2-pcih ligands completing the coordination sphere through axial coordination (a). The Zn(1)-N(11) and Zn(1)-N(12) in all MOFs are of almost identical lengths (Table S1), unlike Zn-O bonds where Zn(1)-O(71) is elongated as compared to the other zinc-oxygen bonds. However, the Zn(1)-O(71) bond in 2 is considerably shorter than in other frameworks (Table S1) which is strictly associated with its noninvolvement in hydrogen bonding, observed for all other MOF structures ().

elements.content: Crystal structure of the {[Zn2(Xiso)2­(pcih)2]·guest} n family (1, 2, 4, 4b). (a) Coordination environment within Zn2 cluster with atom labeling scheme and 30% displacement ellipsoids exemplified for 1. (b) Zinc-isophthalate ribbon chains. (c) Solvent accessible voids were calculated with Mercury software by using a probe molecule with a radius of 1.2 Å: zero-dimensional pores exemplified for 1, also observed for 4, 4b (top); and one-dimensional channels for 2 (bottom). H atoms were omitted for clarity.

Supramolecular interactions involving adjacent layers in the {[Zn2(Xiso)2­(pcih)2]·guest} n family (1, 2, 4, 4b): (a) schematic representation of intermolecular interactions involving two adjacent layers and solvent molecules; (b) arrangement of adjacent layers with separation distances between the planes including zinc-isophthalate chains (H atoms and guest molecules are omitted).
elements.clean_text: 2  Supramolecular interactions involving adjacent layers in the {[Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2]⋅guest} n  family (1, 2, 4, 4b): (a) schematic representation of intermolecular interactions involving two adjacent layers and solvent molecules; (b) arrangement of adjacent layers with separation distances between the planes including zinc-isophthalate chains (H atoms and guest molecules are omitted).

elements.content: The arrangement of alternating AB layers in each framework is governed by supramolecular interactions between the adjacent layers as well as between a layer and interlayer solvent molecules. These interactions are responsible both for out-of-plane displacements in the zinc-isophthalate chains () as well as for the relative arrangement of their planes of propagation between adjacent layers (b). The separations of these planes range from 3.4/11.6 Å for 2 through 6.7/9.0 Å in 1 and 4 to equidistant 7.8/7.8 Å for 4b. In the latter there are no direct interlayer interactions and the layers are positioned through strong framework-guest (N–H)pcih···Oguest and (O–H)guest···Oisophthalate hydrogen bonds [d(N19–O99) = 2.855(4) Å, angle 173(4)°; d(O99–O71#7) = 2.788(4) Å, angle 175(5)°].
elements.clean_text: The arrangement of alternating AB layers in each framework is governed by supramolecular interactions between the adjacent layers as well as between a layer and interlayer solvent molecules. These interactions are responsible both for out-of-plane displacements in the zinc-isophthalate chains () as well as for the relative arrangement of their planes of propagation between adjacent layers (b). The separations of these planes range from 3.4/11.6 Å for 2 through 6.7/9.0 Å in 1 and 4 to equidistant 7.8/7.8 Å for 4b. In the latter there are no direct interlayer interactions and the layers are positioned through strong framework-guest (N-H)pcih⋅⋅⋅Oguest and (O-H)guest⋅⋅⋅Oisophthalate hydrogen bonds [d(N19-O99) = 2.855(4) Å, angle 173(4)°; d(O99-O71#7) = 2.788(4) Å, angle 175(5)°].

elements.content: Contrarily, in the rest of frameworks direct interlayer interactions are observed. In 1 and 4 adjacent sheets interact via strong (N–H)pcih···Oisophthalate hydrogen bonds [d(N39–O71) = 2.820(3) Å, angle 172(4)° for 1; and d(N39–O71) = 2.830(3) Å, angle 172(4)°, d(N19–O88#7) = 2.858(3) Å, angle 172(4)° for 4] between acylhydrazone NH group and carboxylate oxygen (). Additionally in 1 there is a strong (O–H)Xiso···Opcih hydrogen bond [d(O67–O18#7) = 2.797(4) Å, angle 139(3)°] involving polar OH substituent of isophthalate linker and acylhydrazone oxygen atom. The largest deviation from the equidistant separation between the planes of propagation of Zn-Xiso chains is observed in the structure of 2 based on 5-methylisophthalate ions (3.4/11.6 Å). It can be explained by both steric effect as well as polarity of isophthalate substituent. The bigger nonpolar methyl group separates layers, interacting only by weak CH3···π forces with a pyridine ring of pcih from adjacent layer {d[C62-centroid­(N11C12C13C14C15C16)] = 3.88 Å}, whereas polar OH groups (in 1) are engaged in formation of strong hydrogen bonds as donors to an oxygen atom of an acylhydrazone group, mentioned above. This effect is also responsible for different dimensionality of pores in the structures: MOF 2 has one-dimensional bottled-neck type channels propagating along the a axis, as opposed to zero-dimensional cage-like pores observed in other structures ().

This effect is also responsible for different dimensionality of pores in the structures: MOF 2 has one-dimensional bottled-neck type channels propagating along the a axis, as opposed to zero-dimensional cage-like pores observed in other structures ().

elements.content: The infrared spectra of all MOFs {[Zn­(Xiso)2­(pcih)2]­·guest} n (1–4b) (Figure S2) show several characteristic absorption bands corresponding to 5X-1,3-benzenodicarboxylate ions Xiso2–, pcih ligands and guest molecules (H2O, DMA, DMF). The signals in the range 1558–1557 cm–1 and 1385–1399 cm–1 are associated with asymmetric and symmetric vibration of carboxylates, respectively (). The CN absorption band, observed at 1605 cm–1 in the free pcih molecule, is slightly changed for 1–4b (1611–1615 cm–1), as a result of hydrogen bonding interactions. Similar observation is found for carbonyl ν­(CO)pcih stretching vibrations. The most significant difference (above 200 cm–1) between free (3445 cm–1) and MOF incorporated acylhydrazone (in the range 2195–3204 cm–1) is observed for the position of amide N–H bands. These redshifts are caused by formation of hydrogen bonds between N–H groups and isophthalate oxygen (1, 4, 4b) or guest molecules (2).

The signals in the range 1558-1557 cm-1 and 1385-1399 cm-1 are associated with asymmetric and symmetric vibration of carboxylates, respectively (). The CN absorption band, observed at 1605 cm-1 in the free pcih molecule, is slightly changed for 1-4b (1611-1615 cm-1), as a result of hydrogen bonding interactions. Similar observation is found for carbonyl ν(CO)pcih stretching vibrations. The most significant difference (above 200 cm-1) between free (3445 cm-1) and MOF incorporated acylhydrazone (in the range 2195-3204 cm-1) is observed for the position of amide N-H bands. These redshifts are caused by formation of hydrogen bonds between N-H groups and isophthalate oxygen (1, 4, 4b) or guest molecules (2).

For MOFs 1, 2, and 3 additional bands of medium intensity are observed at 3195, 3064, and 3421, 3344 cm–1 which are ascribed to OH, CH3, and NH2 linker substituents, respectively (Figure S2). The broad signal in the range 3572–3345 cm–1 with a maximum at 3462 cm–1 for 4b is associated with vibrations of disordered water molecules occupying interlayer voids. Similar signal is observed for 2 (3572–3345 cm–1 with a maximum at 3503 cm–1). The appearance of an additional strong band, which was observed in the characteristic range for carbonyl groups at 1667–1670 cm–1 and disappeared after the frameworks were thermally activated, confirms the presence of guest DMF molecules in the investigated MOFs (a). Analogous assignments have recently been reported for two interpenetrated 3D frameworks {[Zn2(pdcx)2(pcih)2]·guests}n based on para-dicarboxylic acids (pdcx = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate or 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis carried out for 1–4 revealed for each MOF a stepwise weight loss with a distinct plateau in the range dependent on the substituent of isophthalate linker: OH 230–350; CH3 220–290; NH2 280–340; and H 200–320 °C (). The first step leading to the plateau corresponds to the loss of guest molecules: two DMF and one H2O for 1 (found: 15.6%, calcd weight loss: 14.8%); two DMF and two H2O for 2 (found: 16.1%, calcd weight loss: 16.2%); three DMF for 3 (found: 18.7%, calcd weight loss: 18.9%); and two DMF for 4 (found: 13.9%, calcd weight loss: 13.8%); all molecules given per one Zn2 node unit. The next step with a dTG minimum at 370 (1), 323 (2), 364 (3), and 348 °C (4) is associated with the frameworks decomposition. Main essential factors related to thermal stability of the studied MOFs, i.e., intralayer node-linker bond strengths and the number of linkers connected to each Zn2 node, are the same for all frameworks. However, the degradation temperatures correlate with the type and number of intermolecular forces involving adjacent layers (). Polar substituents (OH, NH2) increase degradation temperatures as compared to the framework with unsubstituted isophthalate linkers (4) through extra involvement in interlayer hydrogen bonding. In contrast, adjacent layers of 2 are connected only by weak CH3-π interaction, which results in the lowest decomposition temperature of all frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Stability

Thermogravimetric analysis carried out for 1-4 revealed for each MOF a stepwise weight loss with a distinct plateau in the range dependent on the substituent of isophthalate linker: OH 230-350; CH3 220-290; NH2 280-340; and H 200-320 °C (). The first step leading to the plateau corresponds to the loss of guest molecules: two DMF and one H2O for 1 (found: 15.6%, calcd weight loss: 14.8%); two DMF and two H2O for 2 (found: 16.1%, calcd weight loss: 16.2%); three DMF for 3 (found: 18.7%, calcd weight loss: 18.9%); and two DMF for 4 (found: 13.9%, calcd weight loss: 13.8%); all molecules given per one Zn2 node unit. The next step with a dTG minimum at 370 (1), 323 (2), 364 (3), and 348 °C (4) is associated with the frameworks decomposition. Main essential factors related to thermal stability of the studied MOFs, i.e., intralayer node-linker bond strengths and the number of linkers connected to each Zn2 node, are the same for all frameworks. However, the degradation temperatures correlate with the type and number of intermolecular forces involving adjacent layers (). Polar substituents (OH, NH2) increase degradation temperatures as compared to the framework with unsubstituted isophthalate linkers (4) through extra involvement in interlayer hydrogen bonding. In contrast, adjacent layers of 2 are connected only by weak CH3-π interaction, which results in the lowest decomposition temperature of all frameworks.

elements.content: Variable-temperature PXRD patterns recorded for 1–4 () indicate that frameworks with polar substituents (1, 3) retain their crystallinity after removing guest molecules before degradation process starts, whereas 2 and 4 lose long distance ordering below the decomposition temperature as indicated by TG measurements (approximately at 140 (2) and 290 °C (4), respectively). On the other hand, guest removal experiments, carried out for 2 and 4 at the temperatures where TGA data () indicated solvent removal only, followed by cooling to room temperature, lead to crystalline phases, different from the initial ones (). This indicates structural flexibility of both frameworks, however, with retention of layered topologies which was confirmed by IR spectra showing intact skeletal vibrations during thermal activation and cooling (see a below).

On the other hand, guest removal experiments, carried out for 2 and 4 at the temperatures where TGA data () indicated solvent removal only, followed by cooling to room temperature, lead to crystalline phases, different from the initial ones (). This indicates structural flexibility of both frameworks, however, with retention of layered topologies which was confirmed by IR spectra showing intact skeletal vibrations during thermal activation and cooling (see a below).

elements.content: Additional chemical stability tests for the frameworks 1–4 were performed in water where the materials remained immersed for 4 days at ambient conditions. The PXRD patterns of all MOFs after such treatment clearly demonstrate that the frameworks with polar substituents on isophthalate linkers (1 and 3) remain unchanged, whereas 2 and 4 undergo structural changes to new crystalline phases (Figure S3 in Supporting Information). Complementary IR spectra for 2 and 4 show only subtle band shifts within the region of skeletal vibrations, which confirms the retention of 2D framework structures during conditioning in water. Thus, similarly as in the case of thermal stability, polar substituents are also responsible for the higher stability of the layered Zn-isophthalate/acylhydrazone frameworks, through their involvement in strong interlayer hydrogen bonding. The weakest interlayer interactions, found for 2, are responsible for the loss of long-range ordering (shown by TD-PXRD) at temperatures much below the onset of thermal degradation of the framework, demonstrated by thermogravimetric studies. Since the latter, along with hydrolytic stability, is mostly governed by the strength of metal-linker coordination bonds, the framework 2 exhibits the lowest degradation temperature as the one with the longest Zn–O bonds (except the bond with oxygen atom that is involved in hydrogen bonding in the rest of frameworks). Similarly, the comparison of Zn–O metal-linker bonds (excluding carboxylate oxygen atoms involved as H-bond acceptors) clearly shows the shortest lengths for 1 which is in agreement with its highest thermal and hydrolytic stability.

The PXRD patterns of all MOFs after such treatment clearly demonstrate that the frameworks with polar substituents on isophthalate linkers (1 and 3) remain unchanged, whereas 2 and 4 undergo structural changes to new crystalline phases (Figure S3 in Supporting Information). Complementary IR spectra for 2 and 4 show only subtle band shifts within the region of skeletal vibrations, which confirms the retention of 2D framework structures during conditioning in water. Thus, similarly as in the case of thermal stability, polar substituents are also responsible for the higher stability of the layered Zn-isophthalate/acylhydrazone frameworks, through their involvement in strong interlayer hydrogen bonding. The weakest interlayer interactions, found for 2, are responsible for the loss of long-range ordering (shown by TD-PXRD) at temperatures much below the onset of thermal degradation of the framework, demonstrated by thermogravimetric studies. Since the latter, along with hydrolytic stability, is mostly governed by the strength of metal-linker coordination bonds, the framework 2 exhibits the lowest degradation temperature as the one with the longest Zn-O bonds (except the bond with oxygen atom that is involved in hydrogen bonding in the rest of frameworks). Similarly, the comparison of Zn-O metal-linker bonds (excluding carboxylate oxygen atoms involved as H-bond acceptors) clearly shows the shortest lengths for 1 which is in agreement with its highest thermal and hydrolytic stability.

elements.content: shows CO2 equilibrium adsorption and desorption isotherms measured at 195 K after thermal activation of the materials 1–4 in a vacuum at 180 °C. Sorption analysis reveals that all activated MOFs (1–4) selectively adsorb smaller CO2 (kinetic diameter = 3.30 Å) over larger N2 (kinetic diameter = 3.64 Å). No significant uptake of nitrogen could be measured at 77 K up to 1 bar. In general, selective adsorption for such interdigitated frameworks can be explained in terms of size or polarity of pores or as a kinetic issue. According to the Zeo++ calculations (see ), both pore window size and maximum pore diameter for 2 are the largest of all frameworks (4.12 and 7.20 Å, respectively). This approximate computation carried out for the as-synthesized framework 2 indicates that N2 molecules should be able to enter its pores, at least in the as-made structure. The rest of the frameworks, exhibiting the same selectivity, have considerably smaller pore window sizes than 2 (), and these are even smaller than kinetic diameter of CO2. Therefore, it seems that in these cases contact with CO2 adsorptive molecules triggers the increase of interlayer pore sizes allowing for internal penetration. In the case of frameworks 2 and 4 structural changes have been observed upon thermal activation as well as upon immersion in water. Thus, in general, selective CO2 versus N2 adsorption behavior in the family of {[Zn­(Xiso)2­(pcih)2]} n MOFs (1–4) can be explained by carbon dioxide affinity toward acylhydrazone groups decorating the framework pores.

p ws, pore windows size; m pd, maximum pore diameter; V pt, theoretical pore volume; V pe, experimental pore volume (based on limiting uptake in the adsorption isotherm). p ws, m pd and V pt were calculated in Zeo+2 software. ν­(C–O) - IR absorption bands recorded during CO2 adsorption at 213 K: ν (C–O) wavenumbers in the C–O vibrations region. FWHM- full width at half maximum of the ν­(C–O) bands.

Pore volume derived from the first plateau at p/p 0 = 0.17 (gas uptake 49 cm3·g–1).

As we reported in our previous paper, the CO2 adsorption curve for 4 has a double step profile with a wide hysteresis caused by the guest-induced framework response (; black line). The first distinct plateau is associated with filling the pore volume of 4 (theoretical/experimental pore volume 0.090/0.087 cm3·g–1, ). The crystal structures of 1 and 3 (isostructurality based on PXRD data) bear a close resemblance to that of 4 ( and ): with zero-dimensional pores between hydrogen-bonded layers in the same arrangement, and the same value of theoretical pore volume (0.090 cm3·g–1, ), therefore should have similar adsorption properties. However, as shown in , the adsorption behavior differs for all compounds, reflecting the differences in interaction of CO2 with linker substituents. The most polar groups in compounds 1 and 3 cause the filling of the pore at lower relative pressure in comparison to unsubstituted compound 4, resulting in type I like isotherms. The stronger affinity to NH2 in comparison to OH is also postulated in the step in the isotherm of 1 within the p/p 0 range of 0.052–0.172, absent in the isotherm of 3. The amount of CO2 adsorbed by materials 1, 3, and 4 reaching nearly the same value at p/p 0 = 0.99 (1: 94.1 cm3·g–1; 3: 95.5 cm3·g–1; 4: 92.4 cm3·g–1) indicates the presence of additional accessible space for each framework (V pe, ) as compared to pore volumes based on crystal structures of as-made materials (V pt, ). However, the energy required for opening the pores in 4 is much higher than in 1 and 3, which is manifested in a distinct intermediate plateau on the adsorption curve of 4.

elements.content: On the other hand, of all studied MOFs, only the framework 2 possesses one-dimensional pores, and their window size is larger (4.12 Å) than the kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.30 Ȧ). Simultaneously it has the highest theoretical pore volume (0.145 cm3·g–1) of all MOFs in the group (). Surprisingly though, the experimental pore volume calculated for {[Zn2(CH3iso)2­(pcih)2]} n (2) based on the maximum amount of adsorbed CO2, V pe = 0.108 cm3·g–1, is considerably lower. It suggests that the structural change the framework 2 undergoes upon thermal activation and cooling, prior to adsorption, is associated with a decrease of available voids ( and ). The ability of 2 to undergo a continuous structural transformation is also manifested in a slope of adsorption branch of the isotherm as well as hysteresis (), in contrast to the rest of {[Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2]} n frameworks. This behavior indicates that CO2 diffusion is the limiting step during the adsorption on activated 2, which also results in a lower uptake of CO2.

elements.content: To get a deeper insight into the adsorption process, the in situ IR spectra before and during adsorption of CO2 on activated samples of 1–4 (after water and DMF removal) were measured. New bands appearing in the IR spectra ( and ) of 1–4 upon CO2 addition, at 2335, 2334, 2333, and 2337 cm–1, respectively, clearly prove that MOFs after evacuation of guest molecules adsorb CO2 at −60 °C. Free carbon dioxide exhibits IR maximum at a higher wavenumber (2345 cm–1), which indicates a slight weakening of C–O bonds upon adsorption, probably by interaction with acylhydrazone groups as well as with substituents of isophthalate ions. The strength of interaction is dependent on the substituent. As shown in b and , the lowest deviation of ν­(C–O) (8 cm–1) compared to free CO2 is observed for the framework based on unsubstituted isophthalate, whereas the highest (12 cm–1) is observed for the one with NH2 substituents. Furthermore, the full width at half-maximum values (fwhm) of the ν­(C–O) band in the spectra of 1–3 also indicate that the isophthalate substituents are engaged in interactions with CO2 adsorptive. Significantly wider signals observed for 1–3 (fwhm = 4.6; 5; 4.5 cm–1, respectively) compared to 4 (fwhm = 3.3 cm–1) can be explained by the increase of the number of intermolecular forces between the framework and adsorbed CO2. The lack of distinct 13CO2 signal, obscured by the main wide band of 12CO2, indicates the presence of nonspecific adsorbate-adsorptive interactions. In addition, the IR spectra of materials 1–4 after evacuation of guest molecules as well as upon CO2 adsorption do not change intralayer coordination bonds, which is confirmed by retention of characteristic bands related to their skeletal vibrations. Collectively, all above-mentioned observations support the hypothesis that the CO2 adsorption occurs in free interlayer spaces of the frameworks, and the substituents are involved in the interactions with the adsorptive.

elements.content: We have synthesized a series of new 2D mixed-linker coordination polymers with an acylhydrazone linker and with either substituted or nonsubstitued isophthalates. The results reveal that all of the MOFs are obtainable by both solution and mechanochemical synthetic methods. Computational data and X-ray structural analysis explained the role of amide groups in selective adsorption of CO2 over N2. In this study we have also demonstrated that exchange of linker substituents lining the pore walls of the frameworks considerably changes interlayer supramolecular interactions and thus layers arrangement, which further entails change of pore volumes, shape, dimensionality, and chemical affinity. As a result the linker substituent affects both thermal and chemical stability of the frameworks as well as adsorption properties. Introducing polar groups on the framework walls increases their stability and affinity to carbon dioxide. The findings provide further instructions for the design of layered, interdigitated frameworks demonstrating selective adsorption and desirable stability.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have synthesized a series of new 2D mixed-linker coordination polymers with an acylhydrazone linker and with either substituted or nonsubstitued isophthalates. The results reveal that all of the MOFs are obtainable by both solution and mechanochemical synthetic methods. Computational data and X-ray structural analysis explained the role of amide groups in selective adsorption of CO2 over N2. In this study we have also demonstrated that exchange of linker substituents lining the pore walls of the frameworks considerably changes interlayer supramolecular interactions and thus layers arrangement, which further entails change of pore volumes, shape, dimensionality, and chemical affinity. As a result the linker substituent affects both thermal and chemical stability of the frameworks as well as adsorption properties. Introducing polar groups on the framework walls increases their stability and affinity to carbon dioxide. The findings provide further instructions for the design of layered, interdigitated frameworks demonstrating selective adsorption and desirable stability.

Carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen were determined by conventional microanalysis with the use of an Elementar Vario MICRO Cube elemental analyzer.

IR spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10 FT-IR spectrophotometer equipped with an iD7 diamond ATR attachment.

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e instrument at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1 in the temperature range of 25–600 °C (approximately sample weight of 50 mg). The measurement was performed at atmospheric pressure under flowing argon.

elements.content: Diffraction intensity data for single crystal of three new compounds (1, 2, and 4b) were collected at 100 K on a KappaCCD (Nonius) diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Cell refinement and data reduction were performed using firmware. Positions of all of non-hydrogen atoms were determined by direct methods using SIR-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. Refinement and further calculations were carried out using SHELXL 2014/7. All hydrogen atoms joined to carbon atoms were positioned with idealized geometries and refined using a riding model with U iso(H) fixed at 1.5 U eq of C for methyl groups and 1.2 U eq of C for other groups. The hydrogen atoms of one water (O99) molecules of 4b (for the second water molecule (O98) hydrogen atoms are indeterminate) and H atoms attached to the N atoms were found in the difference-Fourier map and refined with an isotropic thermal parameter. However, the crystal structure data of 1 and 2 show that the DMF solvents molecules are heavily disordered and were removed using the SQUEEZE procedure implemented in the PLATON package. In the case of 4b the atoms of one of the two H2O solvent molecules were refined using DFIX and DANG instructions. The figures were made using Mercury software. CCDC 1580226, 1580227, 1451728, and 1580228 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for 1, 2, 4, and 4b. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Structure Refinement

Diffraction intensity data for single crystal of three new compounds (1, 2, and 4b) were collected at 100 K on a KappaCCD (Nonius) diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Cell refinement and data reduction were performed using firmware. Positions of all of non-hydrogen atoms were determined by direct methods using SIR-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. Refinement and further calculations were carried out using SHELXL 2014/7. All hydrogen atoms joined to carbon atoms were positioned with idealized geometries and refined using a riding model with U iso(H) fixed at 1.5 U eq of C for methyl groups and 1.2 U eq of C for other groups. The hydrogen atoms of one water (O99) molecules of 4b (for the second water molecule (O98) hydrogen atoms are indeterminate) and H atoms attached to the N atoms were found in the difference-Fourier map and refined with an isotropic thermal parameter. However, the crystal structure data of 1 and 2 show that the DMF solvents molecules are heavily disordered and were removed using the SQUEEZE procedure implemented in the PLATON package. In the case of 4b the atoms of one of the two H2O solvent molecules were refined using DFIX and DANG instructions. The figures were made using Mercury software. CCDC 1580226, 1580227, 1451728, and 1580228 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for 1, 2, 4, and 4b. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

4-Pyridinecarbaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (pcih) (45.2 mg, 0.200 mmol), Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (43.9 mg, 0.200 mmol), and 5-X-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2Xiso) (0.200 mmol, weights given in ) were ground together with 100 μL DMF in a vibrating mill (4 agate balls, 9.5 mm diameter) for 20 min with 15 Hz frequency. The same experiment was repeated in an agate mortar by manual grinding until liquid additive evaporated (grinding times given in ).

4-Pyridinecarboxaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (pcih) (67.9 mg, 0.300 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (89.2 mg, 0.300 mmol), and 5-hydroxy-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2OHiso) (54.6 mg, 0.300 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (15 mL) and H2O (2.0 mL) by sonification (60 s) and heated at 70 °C for 72 h. Yellow crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with DMF, and dried in oven at 60 °C and 500 mbar for 0.5 h. Yield: 105.3 mg (63.4%). Anal. Calc. for C46H44N10O15Zn2: C 49.88, H 4.00, N 12.64%. Found: C 50.76, H 4.00, N 13.24%. FTIR (ATR, cm–1): ν­(OH) 3358m, ν­(NH) 3195m, ν­(CO)pcih 1683s, ν­(CO)DMF 1668s, ν­(CN)pcih 1614m, ν­(COO)as 1558s, ν­(COO)s 1385s.

Synthesis of {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(Meiso)<sub>2</sub>(pcih)<sub>2</sub>]·2DMF·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> in Solution (<bold>2</bold>)

4-Pyridinecarboxaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (pcih) (67.9 mg, 0.300 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (89.2 mg, 0.300 mmol), and 5-methyl-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2Meiso) (54.0 mg, 0.300 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (16 mL) and H2O (1.8 mL) by sonification (60 s) and heated at 70 °C for 96 h. Yellow crystals of 2 were filtered off, washed with DMF, and dried in oven at 60 °C for 0.5 h. Yield: 65.0 mg (38.6%). Anal. Calc. for C48H50N10O14Zn2: Anal. Calc. for C48H50N10O14Zn2: C 51.39, H 4.49, N 12.49%. Found: C 50.66, H 4.19, N 11.91%. FTIR (ATR, cm–1): ν­(NH) 3202m, ν­(CO)pcih 1684m, ν­(CO)DMF 1670s, ν­(CN)pcih 1615s, ν­(COO)as 1557s, ν­(COO)s 1386s.

Synthesis of {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(NH<sub>2</sub>iso)<sub>2</sub>(pcih)<sub>2</sub>]·3DMF}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> in Solution (<bold>3</bold>)

4-Pyridinecarboxaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (pcih) (67.9 mg, 0.300 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (89.2 mg, 0.300 mmol), and 5-hydroxy-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2NH2iso) (54.3 mg, 0.300 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (15 mL) and H2O (2.0 mL) by sonification (60 s) and heated at 70 °C for 60 h. Yellow-brown crystals of 3 were filtered off, washed with DMF, and dried in oven at 60 °C and 500 mbar for 0.5 h. Yield: 126.3 mg (72.5%). Anal. Calc. for C49H51N13O13Zn2: C 50.70, H 4.43, N 15.69%. Found: C 49.97, H 3.97, N 15.28%. FTIR (ATR, cm–1): ν­(NH) 3409w, ν­(NH) 3341w, ν­(NH) 3191m, ν­(CO)pcih 1682m, ν­(CO)DMF 1667s, ν­(CN)pcih 1614m, ν­(COO)as 1557s, ν­(COO)s 1385s.

Synthesis of {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(iso)<sub>2</sub>(pcih)<sub>2</sub>]·2DMA·4H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> in Solution (<bold>4b</bold>)

4-Pyridinecarboxaldehyde isonicotinoyl hydrazone (pcih) (67.9 mg, 0.300 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (89.2 mg, 0.300 mmol), and 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2iso) (49.8 mg, 0.300 mmol) were dissolved in DMA (16 mL) and H2O (1.2 mL) by sonification (60 s) and heated at 50 °C for 7 days Yellow crystals of 4b were filtered off, washed with DMA, and dried in oven at 60 °C and 500 mbar for 0.5 h. Yield: 57.0 mg (32.8%). Anal. Calc. for C48H50N10O14Zn2: C 51.39, H 4.49, N 12.49%. Found: C 52.34, H 4.06, N 12.67%. FTIR (ATR, cm–1): ν­(NH) 3204m, ν­(CO)pcih 1691m, ν­(CO)DMA 1647m, ν­(CN)pcih 1611s, ν­(COO)as 1558s, ν­(COO)s 1394s.

cln_elements.content:
As we reported in our previous paper, the CO2 adsorption curve for 4 has a double step profile with a wide hysteresis caused by the guest-induced framework response (; black line). The first distinct plateau is associated with filling the pore volume of 4 (theoretical/experimental pore volume 0.090/0.087 cm3·g–1, ). The crystal structures of 1 and 3 (isostructurality based on PXRD data) bear a close resemblance to that of 4 ( and ): with zero-dimensional pores between hydrogen-bonded layers in the same arrangement, and the same value of theoretical pore volume (0.090 cm3·g–1, ), therefore should have similar adsorption properties. However, as shown in , the adsorption behavior differs for all compounds, reflecting the differences in interaction of CO2 with linker substituents. The most polar groups in compounds 1 and 3 cause the filling of the pore at lower relative pressure in comparison to unsubstituted compound 4, resulting in type I like isotherms. The stronger affinity to NH2 in comparison to OH is also postulated in the step in the isotherm of 1 within the p/p 0 range of 0.052–0.172, absent in the isotherm of 3. The amount of CO2 adsorbed by materials 1, 3, and 4 reaching nearly the same value at p/p 0 = 0.99 (1: 94.1 cm3·g–1; 3: 95.5 cm3·g–1; 4: 92.4 cm3·g–1) indicates the presence of additional accessible space for each framework (V pe, ) as compared to pore volumes based on crystal structures of as-made materials (V pt, ). However, the energy required for opening the pores in 4 is much higher than in 1 and 3, which is manifested in a distinct intermediate plateau on the adsorption curve of 4.

On the other hand, of all studied MOFs, only the framework 2 possesses one-dimensional pores, and their window size is larger (4.12 Å) than the kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.30 Ȧ). Simultaneously it has the highest theoretical pore volume (0.145 cm3·g–1) of all MOFs in the group (). Surprisingly though, the experimental pore volume calculated for {[Zn2(CH3iso)2­(pcih)2]} n (2) based on the maximum amount of adsorbed CO2, V pe = 0.108 cm3·g–1, is considerably lower. It suggests that the structural change the framework 2 undergoes upon thermal activation and cooling, prior to adsorption, is associated with a decrease of available voids ( and ). The ability of 2 to undergo a continuous structural transformation is also manifested in a slope of adsorption branch of the isotherm as well as hysteresis (), in contrast to the rest of {[Zn2(Xiso)2(pcih)2]} n frameworks. This behavior indicates that CO2 diffusion is the limiting step during the adsorption on activated 2, which also results in a lower uptake of CO2.

The first distinct plateau is associated with filling the pore volume of 4 (theoretical/experimental pore volume 0.090/0.087 cm3⋅g-1, ). However, as shown in , the adsorption behavior differs for all compounds, reflecting the differences in interaction of CO2 with linker substituents. The most polar groups in compounds 1 and 3 cause the filling of the pore at lower relative pressure in comparison to unsubstituted compound 4, resulting in type I like isotherms. The stronger affinity to NH2 in comparison to OH is also postulated in the step in the isotherm of 1 within the p/p 0 range of 0.052-0.172, absent in the isotherm of 3. The amount of CO2 adsorbed by materials 1, 3, and 4 reaching nearly the same value at p/p 0 = 0.99 (1: 94.1 cm3⋅g-1; 3: 95.5 cm3⋅g-1; 4: 92.4 cm3⋅g-1) indicates the presence of additional accessible space for each framework (V pe, ) as compared to pore volumes based on crystal structures of as-made materials (V pt, ). However, the energy required for opening the pores in 4 is much higher than in 1 and 3, which is manifested in a distinct intermediate plateau on the adsorption curve of 4.

On the other hand, of all studied MOFs, only the framework 2 possesses one-dimensional pores, and their window size is larger (4.12 Å) than the kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.30 Ȧ). Simultaneously it has the highest theoretical pore volume (0.145 cm3⋅g-1) of all MOFs in the group (). This behavior indicates that CO2 diffusion is the limiting step during the adsorption on activated 2, which also results in a lower uptake of CO2.
